title_review: A little disappointed with the suckling pig
review_preview: On the whole we had good service. Sat downstairs which has a nice ambience. In our group one of us ordered the traditional starter dish of  grapes  & breadcrumbs which was very dry & different to anything any of us has ever had before. You...
review_full: On the whole we had good service. Sat downstairs which has a nice ambience. In our group one of us ordered the traditional starter dish of grapes & breadcrumbs which was very dry & different to anything any of us has ever had before. You only need to try it once. 3 of us had the suckling pig which was smaller than we have had elsewhere. It was also softer than we have had before because it is boiled, the skin is also soft not at all like the usual crackling, which for my personal taste made it all too fatty, although the meat itself was juicy & tasty. No vegetables with any of dishes. Old school cuisine

title_review: Real Spanish food Close to the Plaza Mayor- Recommended by our Tour guide
review_preview: We did not have a reservation for Xmas Day and our tour guide was able to get us a last minute reservation at this restaurant because we were willing to eat early. It is just off the Plaza Mayor and we felt very lucky to...

It is just off the Plaza Mayor and we felt very lucky to be able to eat here on Xmas day. It was full with locals eating their Xmas traditional spanish dinners. We just ordered the usual Spanish stuff- Paella etc. We did not have any of the tradiitional pig though. We liked it all and had everything from soup to dessert. It is very nice, although we were a bit underdressed as we went last minute. Service was more formal and generally helpful.

review_preview: The hotel where I was staying recommended this eatery as pleasant with good food. They were wrong big time on both counts. Reviewing the menu, myself and my partner  found it challenging to find a dish that wouldn't require our intestinal tracks to work overtime...
review_full: The hotel where I was staying recommended this eatery as pleasant with good food. They were wrong big time on both counts. Reviewing the menu, myself and my partner found it challenging to find a dish that wouldn't require our intestinal tracks to work overtime during the night, thus depriving us of a full night's sleep. Heavy, sleep deprivation dishes. So we opted for what we considered would be a pleasant pre-sleep light dish - salmon with a mushroom risotto. Ooops...... The presentation was acceptable, but as they say, never judge a book by its cover.... The first ‘fork-au-fish into our mouths sent alarm bells ringing. It didn't taste of fish. ' Weird ' I thought to myself, 'it sure looks pink and looks like salmon'. We challenged ourselves again to taste the oddly tasting pink coloured square .... we nearly barfed. The 'thing' tasted old, bordering on putrefaction. We dove into the mushroom risotto. Bad move. It tasted even worse - if that was even possible.... We reached for water to save ourselves from a potential catastrophe at the table. Knife and fork where repositioned back on the plates in a fashion like a castaway on an island places objects on the sand to spell 'SOS'. This was our ‘SOS’…… The waitress came. She was a sweet lady from the Philippines. She looked concerned as she removed the plates. 'Sir it was not good?' she asked as she looked downwards. This was clearly a rhetorical question as the plate had barely been touched. We shook our heads. She continued to look down, winced a smile, and removed the sad offering. We asked for the menu and chose a salad. Well you can’t screw up lettuce..... can you? 10 minutes later our Philippines waitress reappeared and asked if we would be paying for the piscine debacle as if we didn’t, her boss (read ‘ slave owner’) would deduct the cost from her salary. Tears welled in her eyes as she looked for comfort from us. ’Of course we will pay’ we retorted. With tears in her eyes, she smiled, thanked us profusely and looked down sheepishly. She was clearly scared and had clearly been threatened by someone. Fast forward to today and I read with extreme disappointment and anger that the manager of said restaurant had fired the sweet waitress on account of our returning the inedible food. This is totally unacceptable and I would urge the general public to avoid this restaurant until said employee is reinstated. This is a total abuse of authority and is unacceptable in the year 2017. Shame on you Los Galayos and shame on you the Manager!!!

title_review: Good food, relaxed service, amuse bouche and apertif gratis
review_preview: We loved sitting in the Plaza Mayor.  We heard not to order the daily menu, so we ordered al a carte.  We were provided with two gratis amuse bouche - fresh olives and a potato salad with lemon and peas.  Very tasty and enough to...
review_full: We loved sitting in the Plaza Mayor. We heard not to order the daily menu, so we ordered al a carte. We were provided with two gratis amuse bouche - fresh olives and a potato salad with lemon and peas. Very tasty and enough to awaken the palate with a taste of the local cava. The appetizers were the salted cod (bacala), tempura fried. It was excellent and very tasty. This fish has a subtle favor, as it has been first preserved by drying it with salt, It is reconstituted by soaking it in water. Then it's cooked. The end result is a delicate flavor that pairs well with most light whites the Spanish are famous for. The other appetizer was seared foie gras with an onion chutney and Pedro Ximinez reduction. Those who love paring foie and sauterne will find this dish delightful and exciting, as did we. Paired it with a glass of house Sangria. We split an order of suckling pig, which as melt in your mouth good. The skin was crispy and chewy without being the least bit rubbery. More Sangria. We skipped dessert, but were offered a spice and fruit infused grappa that was a perfect digestive for such a rich meal. Not diet food, but we don't count calories when on holiday. Recommend it, and will do it again if ever in Madrid.

title_review: Fascinating location, nice atmosphere, good food and decent service
review_preview: I enjoyed a business dinner at Los Galayos in November 2013 and it was a pleasant experience. The location, straight on Plaza Mayor, is surely fascinating. The restaurant (we booked the entire upper floor) is stylish, comfortable and intimate at the same time. The food...
review_full: I enjoyed a business dinner at Los Galayos in November 2013 and it was a pleasant experience. The location, straight on Plaza Mayor, is surely fascinating. The restaurant (we booked the entire upper floor) is stylish, comfortable and intimate at the same time. The food was simple but VERY well cooked, tasty and came in abundant portions. I was also positively surprised by the wine. We were served bottles of some local wines that were looking suspiciously cheap. They turned out to contain some of the best wine I had in a long time. On the downside I was not particularly impressed by the service. Waiters and waitresses know little or none English and they weren't quite elegant/professional as you would expect considering both the overall quality of the place and, according to others reviews I read, the price tag.

title_review: Food on the beach in Madrid!!
review_preview: Wandering around Madrid we fell upon this little gem of a restaurant.It was a gloriously sunny day so all outdoor tables were taken and had a mighty wait but we were offered a table in the basement. We were warned there were low tables...
review_full: Wandering around Madrid we fell upon this little gem of a restaurant. It was a gloriously sunny day so all outdoor tables were taken and had a mighty wait but we were offered a table in the basement. We were warned there were low tables but we were quite expecting the beach bar we found ourselves in!!  The tables and chairs were a few inches off the floor and the floor was covered in sand! The 15 year old in our party was in her element; cool and trendy!! There was an extensive menu with plenty of non meat options for us fussy eaters and the cocktail and drinks menu was fantastic. The food and drinks were great and the service as expected in Spain... we weren't in a hurry; the table of Spanish girls on a hen party kept us entertained!! Would certainly go for a return visit but would try to secure a table ground level and leave the basement for the youngsters!!

review_preview: Have been going to En Busca del Tiempo for about 15 years. They have great toasts for a mid morning breakfast right in the heart of the city - so you can fuel up for great shopping and lots of walking.My favorite is the...
review_full: Have been going to En Busca del Tiempo for about 15 years. They have great toasts for a mid morning breakfast right in the heart of the city - so you can fuel up for great shopping and lots of walking. My favorite is the Jamon Iberico - with good rustic bread a light but tasty tomato spread and the best of spanish jamon. I have also enjoyed evenings here - a few years back, my spouse and I took 3 teens to Spain for a trip over Christmas and New Years. We enjoyed a wonderful tapas meal here on Christmas eve with Prawns in a Cream Sherry sauce that was out of this world. Wine is always priced well and very good quality. I love the glasses. Be prepared to sit on hard wood stools and experience Spain like a local in this old-style bar and restaurant. Service is typically Spanish - you must ask for your check and don't expect it to be super fast.

review_preview: I was staying at the Hostal Alhambra Suites at Sol, Madrid, about 50 metres away from this restaurant. El Busco provides the complimentary breakfast for guests staying at Alhambra Suites. It’s a full-fledged cozy restaurant with an extension across the street. I can comment only...
review_full: I was staying at the Hostal Alhambra Suites at Sol, Madrid, about 50 metres away from this restaurant. El Busco provides the complimentary breakfast for guests staying at Alhambra Suites. It’s a full-fledged cozy restaurant with an extension across the street.  I can comment only on the breakfast that I had there for 5 days in a row. The service is quick and one can choose from a small buffet with Spanish hams, breads, muffins and fruit especially the delicious melon.  You can also choose to have the large rustic bread slices toasted and with a topping that’s a la carte (included as complimentary). It’s a great way to have a taste of authentic Spanish cuisine even at breakfast. The little crusty ultra-mini baguettes (picos de pan) were a novelty! Wholesome breakfast and strong coffee!

title_review: Perfect evening with food and friends!
review_preview: I visited En Busch del Tiempo whilst on my last evening in Madrid. The bar was hidden in a little street not to far from Sol. The welcome was very friendly and they gave us a lovely table by the window. The bar was on...
review_full: I visited En Busch del Tiempo whilst on my last evening in Madrid. The bar was hidden in a little street not to far from Sol. The welcome was very friendly and they gave us a lovely table by the window. The bar was on two levels. As walk in, there is a bar and to the left is where you can sit for food. The ambience was for a traditional tapas bar with low lighting with red and orange tones. There were many tables occupied with laughing groups of friends - from all around the world!  The wine bottles started from €16.50 a bottle. We shared a lovely Rioja wine and they have us a tapas dish to share. The first tapas dish they have us was small cubes potatoes with sausage, tomato and peppers - delicious! They also have us another tapas dish which consisted of baked bread with a creamy smoked salmon and red onion topping. I'm going to attempt to make this at home!  We ordered to large tapas dishes to share - fish and meat. The portions were just right for two people to share.  This is definitely a gem to remember when I return to Madrid!

title_review: The waiter, Felix, made our dinner one of the best!
review_preview: We ate here 3 days ago with our 4 children under the age of 12.  We live in NY where steak is everywhere and delicious!  They LOVED eating here given that the screaming hot plate and raw meat came to the table with sea salt....
review_full: We ate here 3 days ago with our 4 children under the age of 12. We live in NY where steak is everywhere and delicious! They LOVED eating here given that the screaming hot plate and raw meat came to the table with sea salt. We ordered 1.5k the first time and we all shared. Beyond Delicious.  The kids kept begging us to return. Our second experience was nearly ruined because our waiter was clueless. I found Felix, he remembered us, brought out a new kilo of raw meat, a new hot rock and the kids were over the moon. He didn't charge us the second round and in good faith, brought us after dinner drinks to the alley. He was by far, the most attentive and responsive waiter we've had in Madrid! If you're near Puerta Del Sol, walk up to this hidden gem. The steak on the rock was amazing and Felix is the biggest reason to go back multiple times. My kids may not remember the Prado, but they'll remember him!

title_review: Nice but not great, slightly overrated
review_preview: We love the idea of the fusion of Japanese and Spanish, all for the better for a lighter meal on a hot night.We arrived at the restaurant at 8:30pm on a Thursday night and it was nearly full. The male waiter at the counter...
review_full: We love the idea of the fusion of Japanese and Spanish, all for the better for a lighter meal on a hot night. We arrived at the restaurant at 8:30pm on a Thursday night and it was nearly full. The male waiter at the counter was annoyed that we did not book for a table. Bluntly said to us that there were only seats along the windows available. We said we didn't mind. Quite a long while after we sat down, there were still no waiters come and explain to us how we should order as we have no idea how big the dishes is and how much we should order. All the waiters keep walking past us, looking stressed but none of them look at us or offer their service. This was quite annoying. Finally a female waiter come to take our order. I asked her in English to recommend a dry white. She suddenly gave out a grunt then squished her head and left. We wondered what happened and later another female waiter come and helped with our wine order. We just understood that the first female waiter didn't speak English. After ordering a bottle of wine, we thought the same English speaking waiter would come back to take our food order but she just disappeared to another section. After quite a while, we nearly finished our first glass if wine. The first female waiter who doesn't speak English come back to take our food order. This time she brought along a Spanish language menu, so when we point at the items on our English menu, she referred to her Spanish menu.  She also explained to us that for two of us, we need to order at least five items to share. Most of dishes come in two small pieces except those stated on the menu one piece. The five dishes come randomly from about 10 minutes to an hour.  Strips of beef with special barbecue sauce 5.10€ - From Yakibonakas Spiced rice, grilled over charcoal in a banana leaf 3.90€ - On the side Variegated scallop, lime and ají amarillo chili ceviche 5.90€ - From the water Crispy fried chicken with a sweet and sour cañí sauce 5.20€ - From the farmyard Wagyu ribs meat, grilled in teriyaki sauce 7.20€ - From the ranch All the items are really tasty but the serving was really small for the price they charged. Only the chicken and the rice dishes are quite enough for two persons to share. The other three dishes were just a little too mean and we would need to order one serving for each person and we are not big eaters, two servings if you are a big eater. We love the deco and think the design is great. We love how the seats slightly swirl out from the kitchen in the middle of the large room and those big windows.  We found the dining experience was good because the vibes were great. If the experience had not been let down by rude waiters and some of the dishes could be certainly be more generous for the price.

title_review: Excellent food, staff in need of some training
review_preview: As fans of yakitori style cooking in Japan, it was interesting to try out a Spanish version. Between the two of us, we ordered five dishes, plus a side of rice. All the food, two vegetable dishes, one fish and two meat were beautifully cooked...
review_full: As fans of yakitori style cooking in Japan, it was interesting to try out a Spanish version. Between the two of us, we ordered five dishes, plus a side of rice. All the food, two vegetable dishes, one fish and two meat were beautifully cooked and very tasty - when they arrived. Initially the rice and two other dishes arrived, then after some wait the waitress asked us if anything was missing. We had to explain what had arrived and what else was yet to come. We had an English and a Spanish menu between us, but a little later when two people came in and asked for an English menu, the waitress just shook her head. Maybe we were lucky in that it was quiet when we arrived but by the time the other couple arrived, it was very busy. The food was washed down with 'El Sentido", a very tasty Ribera del Duero.

review_preview: Where do I begin? Ok. The positive. Nice atmosphere. Now the bad. The food. The menu is a mess. Whatever Japanese Spanish Tapas Fusion idea the chef had does not work. Tried several of the yaki skewer type dishes and they were either bland, buried...
review_full: Where do I begin? Ok. The positive. Nice atmosphere. Now the bad. The food. The menu is a mess. Whatever Japanese Spanish Tapas Fusion idea the chef had does not work. Tried several of the yaki skewer type dishes and they were either bland, buried in sauce, not aesthetically pleasing or all of the above. Looking for something more substantial I noticed the YakiRamen dishes. I asked the waitress if they were in fact noodle dishes as the name would imply and she said yes. Again a disaster. Not really ramen. A heavy bowl of sauce with a few pieces of calamari and muscles. And at 12 euros for that and approximately 6-8 euros for the small tapa skewers it was a lot to pay for very overrated food. Can't understand the ratings so high when I can think of many better options in Madrid. If you want Japanese go elsewhere. If you want tapas, there are traditional and non-traditional options throughout Madrid at reasonable prices. You can even find Asian fusion elsewhere more appetizing. This entire experience was painful and pretentious. And no point of drowning the experience in sorrow with beer and wine prices also ridiculously high for Madrid. I rarely come down so hard on a place in a restaurant review but if not for the location and atmosphere I can't imagine there being many repeat customers.

review_preview: This was our first snack during a recent trip to Spain.  A neighborhood café that met our desire for some of Spain’s good stuff. A nice plate of Manchego, callos con grabanzos, some jamon, more snacks and a nice bottle of Spanish wine (Vivanco from...
review_full: This was our first snack during a recent trip to Spain. A neighborhood café that met our desire for some of Spain’s good stuff. A nice plate of Manchego, callos con grabanzos, some jamon, more snacks and a nice bottle of Spanish wine (Vivanco from La Rioja). Our server was outstanding. Not too far geographically from the Plaza Mayor, but worlds away from the tourist restaurants in the center city. Take the walk, have a nice meal and explore the neighborhood. Bonus: visit the nearby Mercado de Antón Martín.

title_review: Free pour gin of truly epic proportions!!
review_preview: I can honestly say this is one of the best Bars in Madrid and we visited many! The staff were so welcoming and friendly, happy for us to indulge in some badly accented and grammatically poor Spanish, appreciative of our efforts if not our ability....
review_full: I can honestly say this is one of the best Bars in Madrid and we visited many! The staff were so welcoming and friendly, happy for us to indulge in some badly accented and grammatically poor Spanish, appreciative of our efforts if not our ability. The wine list is extensive, excellent and really good value. The tapas is excellent, but the highlight for some of us apart from the Rioja, is the free poured Gin & Tonic! If you like your Gin go here, the I would say Triple Gin (Tanqueray) free poured into the fishbowl glass to the millimetre with a practised eye, filled up with tonic, ice and lemon is excellent value at only 9 euro. review_preview: You can't beat Stop Madrid  Cervecería ....in Calle Hortaleza 11 Madrid for a very authentic Saturday lunch.  I began with a pinta of Koenig Pilsner which arrived with a tapa of green olives.  I ordered a canapé of Gulas ( baby eels) €4 and a...
review_full: You can't beat Stop Madrid Cervecería ....in Calle Hortaleza 11 Madrid for a very authentic Saturday lunch. I began with a pinta of Koenig Pilsner which arrived with a tapa of green olives. I ordered a canapé of Gulas ( baby eels) €4 and a tapa of Manchego cheese €7. The atmosphere was humming to the beat of flamenco, the locals were doing what all Spaniards do...talking rapidly at the tops of their lungs . Seating is at a premium so you may have to prop yourself at the bar before a table becomes available. There's also a great selection of wines by the glass or a bottle if you're feeling up to it. You'll love it!

title_review: japanese tapas in very relaxed attitude
review_preview: had reservations for six in the castillana around 16 o'clock. Luckily it was at end of spanish lunch time so it was quite empty and food arrived fast. Tables are really close together - no privacy but clever idea of a storing stool per table...
review_full: had reservations for six in the castillana around 16 o'clock. Luckily it was at end of spanish lunch time so it was quite empty and food arrived fast. Tables are really close together - no privacy but clever idea of a storing stool per table for your bags and stuff... alcoholic drinks are on the rocks in the middle of the table, soft drinks and water have to be ordered. Music is very cool indy rock, restaurant nicely decorated with insulation material witch creats good acoustics! Food is a true fusion of spanish tapas with (mainly) japanese preparation techniques (yakitori barbacue) and different asian sauces. All we chose were very good - also good value size to price. Especially good: wagiu beef, meat balls, cheese cake and wasabi ice cream. Serving of food was friendly but a bit unorganised (side dishes were served first, then different tapas dropped, but not according to guests orders... as we shared most that was not tragic, but if it is more full and you have to wait for your dish it might be annoying). Surely will repeat - but again at off hours to avoid crowds.

review_preview: I love stumbling upon a gem like this. We'd decided on a steak from the grill house over the road and when we got there despite a large sign saying "abierto" and the doors being open and the waiters being on the floor, they decided...
review_full: I love stumbling upon a gem like this. We'd decided on a steak from the grill house over the road and when we got there despite a large sign saying "abierto" and the doors being open and the waiters being on the floor, they decided they weren't open for an hour! Why do restaurants do this? Anyway, we hit trip advisor and across the road is this highly rated Japanese tapas bar. We weren't really in the mood for tapas but it was this or maybe something rubbish after a long walk, so we got there in 3 mins. The (manager) looked up from his laptop as we entered and said hello and advised we could only have the table for 2 hours (who spends longer in a tapas bar?) but he seemed friendly enough, the place was large with lots of free tables at 6pm. We asked the cute waitress if she spoke English and with a stern look as if I'd asked for her phone number she said "no" but she was beautiful so it only made us like her more. We were given English menus and they revealed some really interesting menu items, all tapas priced, about 4 to 6 euro each. We went for safe options, deep fried cod bites, lamb with tzatki, chicken meatballs and a beefburger in some kind of soy sauce. Although the meatballs were a little cold (may have been the style) the food was fantastic. Not massive portions but enough to get the flavour of the dish. The other waitresses were smilier but not as attractive as the first. When she brought our beefburger we got her to say beefburger and this actually raised a smile from her which pushed the review from 4 to 5 stars. So back to the food. We decided on another dish of pork in a spicy sauce which was great then we opted for dessert, apple pie and ice cream for me and white chocolate for my friend, both of them would bring a tear to a glass eye and put your grandmother out of business. The bill including drinks was 39 euro, so about 16 quid each for one of my favourite meals. We need places like this in the UK, simply awesome.

title_review: An Excellent Alternative for Suckling Pig
review_preview: If you want to eat in the oldest restaurant in Madrid (and the world I believe) and you want suckling pig, everyone tells you go to Rest. B. Just make sure you book your reservation many days in advance. If you are looking for an...
review_full: If you want to eat in the oldest restaurant in Madrid (and the world I believe) and you want suckling pig, everyone tells you go to Rest. B. Just make sure you book your reservation many days in advance. If you are looking for an excellent alternative for suckling pig, then try Los Galayos right off the Plaza de Mayor. They offer high quality Castilian cuisine and have been doing it since 1894. We started with a salad topped with burratta cheese, which was excellent and we both went for the suckling pig. The skin was crispy and delicious and the meat just fell off the bone. The scalloped potatoes complemented the pork very well. The only problem with the entire meal is that we chose to sit inside. There was apparently a tour group of about 30 there having dinner and they were a bit noisy especially after drinking some wine. There are two outside areas where you can also be seated…right in front of the restaurant or on the Plaza de Mayor itself. We didn’t know this seating was available as we made a reservation through the concierge at our hotel. I think we would have chosen outside on the plaza, especially on such a beautiful evening.

Decor is elegant and the atmosphere is fun. This is not a haute-gastronomic life-changing food pilgrimage, but the dishes are all delicious, interesting and timed well. The service was very friendly, uniforms are a bit whacky, TOP-GUN airforce jumpsuits (not joking) but it's all part of the experience. We sat by the window on short stools but there are loads of tables too. Bathrooms are a bit confusing but that's hardly a criticism. The place was hopping on a Wednesday night which says a lot, GO!

review_preview: We were in Yakitoro by Chicote (Calle Reina, 41) for celebrating a birthday as a couple. It was an amazing atmosphere with a short but interesting menu. Prices are acceptable but if you want to have your dinner or lunch there, you need to order...
review_full: We were in Yakitoro by Chicote (Calle Reina, 41) for celebrating a birthday as a couple.  It was an amazing atmosphere with a short but interesting menu.  Prices are acceptable but if you want to have your dinner or lunch there, you need to order at least 5-6 tapas to share (2 people). In the end, if you order 6 tapas and 2-3 drinks, the bill is round 40-45 euro.  Each plate is like a tapa to share. They offer you a food you are familiar but with a speacial touch on them. Taste of all plates are amazing!!  The waiters are friendly and nice.  By the way, It is so close to Banco de Espana (Linea 2)  I certainly reccommend this place to go :)  Enjoy it:)

title_review: Good beef and tasty potatoes average service
review_preview: We were welcomed by a very warm and friendly hostess that seated us and took our order.  The waiter was ok, not terribly attentive despite that fact that there weren't very many customers there. We got the beef you grill at the table - very...

The waiter was ok, not terribly attentive despite that fact that there weren't very many customers there. We got the beef you grill at the table - very nice accompanied with a small side of tender potatoes- they kindly brought us more when we requested them. When it came time to pay, the waiter asked us if we wanted to put the tip on the credit card or to leave cash - we felt a bit uncomfortable and left a generous tip because they did give us more potatoes when we asked for them, but upon reflection, we realized that he shouldn't have done that. The dining room was pleasant and considering it's location to place Mayor, it isn't "touristy."

review_preview: Situated in Plaza Mayor, is one of the oldest restaurants in Madrid. The place is cozy. The waitstaff is attentive and accommodating. Cesar, in particular, greeted us with a smile and was helpfulin choosing our meal. We had the paella mixta which is a...
review_full: Situated in Plaza Mayor, is one of the oldest restaurants in Madrid. The place is cozy. The waitstaff is attentive and accommodating. Cesar, in particular, greeted us with a smile and was helpful in choosing our meal. We had the paella mixta which is a mixture of meats, seafood and vegetables. Like any paella, you wait for about 25 minutes for it to cook. While waiting, they provided us with olives and a tuna spread with a big bread. We were only able to finish one bread among the 3 of us, unless we wanted to ruin our appetite. The paella was flavorful and cooked just right. The squid was tender as well as the other meats in it. We also had Cochinilla, roasted suckling pig. The meat was tender and juicy while the skin is crispy. The bacalao was a welcome addition to our meal. Again, these people know how to cook as the fish was tender and juicy without the fishy smell or taste. We were too full for dessert. We even had our leftovers to go. They have us lychee schnapps at the end of our meal which was actually good, not the usual cough syrup taste I've had in the past. It was a good experience, all in all.

title_review: Great Spanish Food on Plaza Mayor
review_preview: The hotel Concierge recommended this restaurant to us, located in the Plaza Mayor.  Kinda touristy but it was a good bet.  We also found out, after arriving, that they had a book of gin and tonic drinks that must have had 100 different drinks made...
review_full: The hotel Concierge recommended this restaurant to us, located in the Plaza Mayor. Kinda touristy but it was a good bet. We also found out, after arriving, that they had a book of gin and tonic drinks that must have had 100 different drinks made with various gin and tonic. I selected Hendricks Gin and Tonic and the waiter made the presentation of making this drink a major affair. Ice arrived in a huge goblet. He then poured a large shot of Hendricks Gin down the handle of a long spoon, creating almost no bubbles. He then added a cucumber. It was a very delightful drink. Even though it was 11 Euros, I still ordered two. The local fare is good also. Try their specialty, grilled, succulent, young pig. Crispy skin on the outside and wonderful pork on the inside. A bit noisy in the surroundings due to being on the Plaza, but all in all a nice evening with good food.

review_preview: We had booked ahead on the basis of a recommendation and for some reason they tried to give us a table in the alley (overlooking a calamari sandwich shop!) rather than in the main square - my advice is to hold out for a table...
review_full: We had booked ahead on the basis of a recommendation and for some reason they tried to give us a table in the alley (overlooking a calamari sandwich shop!) rather than in the main square - my advice is to hold out for a table in the square. Waiters very friendly but English is limited. In common with most Brits abroad we over ordered and too much food came to the table - here I would be critical of the waiters as when we asked the portion sizes they indicated a plate much smaller than actually came. Our fault but they could have guided us better! Food was great ( paella and calamari ) wine was lovely. The bill came to about Euro 50 each. They do charge for bread rolls whether you have them or not and they delivered a full jug of sangria even though we only ordered a half jug. Overall though any niggles were more than compensated by the fab location and the bustle of the plaza major.

So much so, we returned on our last evening and tried the suckling pig..... What a treat!!! Pedro was not around and the service was not as attentive, hence the the 4 star review. Don't let that put you off.... Go try, you will not be disappointed in the food!

title_review: Not quite the oldest but better.........
review_preview: This restaurant was recommended to us by the concierge at The Palacio de Tepa Hotel (see review) and proved to be a first rate choice. It has been in existence since 1894 and a favourite of Madrids great debaters and intellectuals since the '30's. Take...
review_full: This restaurant was recommended to us by the concierge at The Palacio de Tepa Hotel (see review) and proved to be a first rate choice. It has been in existence since 1894 and a favourite of Madrids great debaters and intellectuals since the '30's. Take time to have a wander around it, particularly downstairs where you can see old historic photos of the people who have visited over the years and the well stocked wine cellar. Also downstairs are the spotlessly clean and attractive toilets. The staff are friendly and were very helpful when it came to menu choices for my coeliac partner who rated their warm gluten free bread the best she had ever had. The wine list was excellent and not overpriced, all the wines listed showed their regions of origin and producers. On our first visit we chose the shrimps in garlic oil for starters and veal for our main course.Mine came in the form of a veal steak sliced into thin slices which you cooked yourself on a hot stone on the table whilst S's was a grilled cutlet. We never did find out why hers was different to mine but it had something to do with being gluten free. We suspect that it was probably because mine was dusted with flour before being flash browned on the outside before being brought to the table. The only slight niggle was the usual problem of the vegetables not being piping hot which seems the norm in Spain. A flask of peach and cinnamon liqueur compliments of the house was brought to the table after we had finished eating and this happened again when we went there for lunch on our last day. On that occasion we both had the Paella Mixta which contained squid, chicken, rabbit and prawns and which we rated the best ever. An altogether great restaurant, easily found near the Plaza Mayor and well worth a visit.

review_preview: Los Galayos is not to be missed if you are in Madrid. Go to Plaza Mayor, the great ceremonial space near Puerta del Sol. At the southern end of the plaza, there are two archways leading to side streets. C/Botoneras is the one at the...
review_full: Los Galayos is not to be missed if you are in Madrid. Go to Plaza Mayor, the great ceremonial space near Puerta del Sol. At the southern end of the plaza, there are two archways leading to side streets. C/Botoneras is the one at the left-hand arch as you look from Calle Mayor. Los Galayos is the first building on the left and even has overflow tables in that corner of the plaza itself if you want to eat al fresco. Wonderful food -- everything from tapas and pinchos to full sit-down meals. Signature dish is their superb suckling pig. Excellent wine list, very well priced. Staff friendly and helpful, many of them speaking English. Go there and enjoy!

title_review: Really enjoyable, excellent service, good food, very reasonable prices
review_preview: This was our last evening in Madrid and we wanted a good meal in the lovely area of the Plaza Mayor. Having read other reviews on TA we thought this would be just right, an it certainly was.Our waitress was helpful and made sure...
review_full: This was our last evening in Madrid and we wanted a good meal in the lovely area of the Plaza Mayor. Having read other reviews on TA we thought this would be just right, an it certainly was. Our waitress was helpful and made sure that we understood the menu, which helped. We ordered a glass of Sangria each and it arrived in a really large tumbler and was absolutely delicious. We had the Tempura Cod, which was just superb cooked to perfection with good sized portions, we also had the Asparagus spears with Aioli sauce and some ham and cheese croquettes, for the two of us there were 8 pieces of each of f the dishes so really more than enough, especially as we'd been given a tasty amuse bouche and a bowl of olives to start, with our Sangria. After the meal I had a very good cafe solo and we were presented with a small carafe and 2 glasses of the best Grappa I've ever enjoyed. A really excellent meal and all this for €50.50. Absolutely a restaurant we have no hesitation in recommending to anyone fortunate enough to have the chance of enjoying a meal here. Thank you for your kind hospitality.

review_preview: This place is in my top 5 of of bars in Madrid.  On our third visit to Madrid, we visit every time.The smallish cosy bar used to be a butcher shop and the ceramic white tiles remain.  The walls are covered with bottles of...
review_full: This place is in my top 5 of of bars in Madrid. On our third visit to Madrid, we visit every time. The smallish cosy bar used to be a butcher shop and the ceramic white tiles remain. The walls are covered with bottles of wine etc. The place fills up quickly with people enjoying the wines and atmosphere. The place is run by just a couple of staff and the owner works very hard. Cold dry fino sherry is on offer, as is vermouth from the tap, a selection of white & red wines and beer. All at excellent prices. With every drink you get small free tapa. The smoked black sausage was delicious, as was the mussels and olives tasty and garlicky. Also the blue cheese & cambembert of toast is a good cheap filler. The wines are delicious and served nice and cold. The service is prompt. Would be happy to have a bar like this as my local. Keep up the good work. You deserve your success.

title_review: Super slow service and extremely overcooked dishes
review_preview: We vistited Galayos with a native of Madrid, not because she knew the place, but because of the location.  They seated us very quickly foe lunch.  We arrived around 3 p.m., perfect time for lunch.  We ordered the daily menu, which was about 12€ each....
review_full: We vistited Galayos with a native of Madrid, not because she knew the place, but because of the location. They seated us very quickly foe lunch. We arrived around 3 p.m., perfect time for lunch. We ordered the daily menu, which was about 12€ each. Among us, we ordered a salad, gazpacho soups and a seafood stew. It arrived within 20 minutes and was great. But then, after ordering the entrees (swordfish, tuna and rabbit), it was easily 40 minutes....the swordfish was SO dry, and served with tartar sauce (bad sign, good fish doesn't come with tartar sauce). The swordfish was alwful, as was the rabbit, overcooked and dry. It was ONLY the tuna, cooked in a nice red sauce, that was edible. We were really disappointed. Clearly someone forgot about our order at some point. Not recommended, nor will we return.

title_review: Madrid Los Galayos is part of the history of the city
review_preview: In Madrid there are many places to choose from and most are really good, Los Galayos offers excellent Sangria, torreznos Ibericos (pork) is to die for and would recommend all the pork dishes. The Paella Mixta with seafood, pork, chicken is pretty good but not...
review_full: In Madrid there are many places to choose from and most are really good, Los Galayos offers excellent Sangria, torreznos Ibericos (pork) is to die for and would recommend all the pork dishes. The Paella Mixta with seafood, pork, chicken is pretty good but not the best around. The staff is way above average and the location in the Mayors plaza is romantic, looking around an area you see the place come to life with activity and you want to be there, its the real Madrid scene.

title_review: Nice food! Pleasant place! Service veeeeeeeeeeeery ry slow
review_preview: I was recommended this place by a 5 star hotel concierge as the best one!! Well, it's good, but definitely not the best! The food is good, I ate paella marisco/seafood. Of course I have to admit there is no place outside Valencia where I...
review_full: I was recommended this place by a 5 star hotel concierge as the best one!! Well, it's good, but definitely not the best! The food is good, I ate paella marisco/seafood. Of course I have to admit there is no place outside Valencia where I could taste a real paella! However it was still very good! The restaurant was kind enough to allow me to order an individual paella, although there is not such thing in the menu! Everything is for minimum 2 people in the menu! But ask if you want! Also it was big enough to share between two people if you also order other tapas and assume this is one of the tapas too!  All in all it was a pleasant atmosphere, good Spanish food for tourists! Only problem it was too slow! They mention it takes about 25 minutes to cook paella! But I was waiting for about 1hour and 10 minutes to be served! I aimed for a quick dinner and ended up with a very long one! And it wasn't even busy! So decide according to your time! Also value for money is okeyish! I have tried much better food in Madrid for the same price.

title_review: Los Galayos - on Plaza Mayor, but not a tourist trap
review_preview: The restaurant is in a corner of the square. Food and service is of very good quality. And pricing is on level with many other good restaurants of similar quality, so don't miss the opportunity to eat here just because you could believe it is...
review_full: The restaurant is in a corner of the square. Food and service is of very good quality. And pricing is on level with many other good restaurants of similar quality, so don't miss the opportunity to eat here just because you could believe it is "for tourists only" The A la carte dishes are many and varied. We had baby lamb cutlets and suckling pig. Excellent and tasty! The pan is among the best you will get in a restaurant. Wine list extensive, and many of them very reasonably priced. Service very professionel.  You feel very wellcome in Los Galayos. Try it.

I was seated at an indoor table, which was fine with me. I ordered seafood for my main course, and it was excellent! Indeed, everything else I ate here was great! The service was very helpful, as an English menu was provided for me, and the waitstaff knew enough English to keep me happy. Furthermore, this group of musicians wandered around the establishment, serenading customers with traditional Spanish songs. Overall, this was a fantastic dining experience, one which I highly recommend!

title_review: Dinner for the Price of a Couple of Beers
review_preview: Stumbled across this place when looking for El Tigre up the block, which was closed.  Ordered a couple of beers, and the beers and tapas just kept coming, like they didn't want us to leave!  We were stuffed full of food -- mostly fried potatoes,...
review_full: Stumbled across this place when looking for El Tigre up the block, which was closed. Ordered a couple of beers, and the beers and tapas just kept coming, like they didn't want us to leave! We were stuffed full of food -- mostly fried potatoes, croquetas, tortilla, etc. I couldn't understand how they were able to make any money with all of the food sent our way. Definitely found better quality tapas in other places, but this place was all about quantity and getting to know the gregarious staff -- Martin and the others were incredible: fun, sweet, chatty, informative. On our second visit we were treated to jamon y queso and also some paella in addition to the normal fare. The place is jostling and busy, seems to cater to a young but divers crowd, and is a cheap way to fill up before going out or to cap off a night of drinking. Our first visit we probably had 10 or 12 beers, plate after plate after plate of tapas, some digestivos, and also shots of something particularly potent and homemade (after closing, of course!). The bill? 27 euros.

title_review: For the price, cannot beat it!
review_preview: Nothing fancy, but for a snack or simple meal, you can't beat a 1 euro sandwich!  There are actually many locations throughout the city, but it doesn't feel touristy at all.  My husband and I stopped in  early evening and both the man behind the...
review_full: Nothing fancy, but for a snack or simple meal, you can't beat a 1 euro sandwich! There are actually many locations throughout the city, but it doesn't feel touristy at all. My husband and I stopped in early evening and both the man behind the counter who served us and those around us were all Spanish speakers. And actually the guy serving us seemed annoyed to have foreigners in, but I actually kind of liked it since anything that caters too much to tourists feels cheesy, ha. We ordered a chorizo sandwich and a salami sandwich, and two drinks. Sandwiches are literally meat on bread, nothing else, but meat and bread were good so no complaints! Also, two mini sandwiches came with our two drinks (which we didn't get at first and let sit on the counter). Total bill was 4 euros (1 euro each for the 2 sandwiches and the 2 drinks) - nuts!

title_review: Mi corazón and my tummy are both llenos y contentos
review_preview: I walked out with a full heart and full tummy! Having lived in Spain twice, there are certain things I can't do without when I'm here, one of which is a truly authentic tapas bar. Not the busy commercial ones you find on the big...
review_full: I walked out with a full heart and full tummy!  Having lived in Spain twice, there are certain things I can't do without when I'm here, one of which is a truly authentic tapas bar. Not the busy commercial ones you find on the big streets who overcharge, but the small bar with amazing food you find on the smaller streets. I can happily say that while I hadn't been here before, I have found my new favorite spot at Bar Respiro. I will be here every time I come to Madrid moving forward!  The food was excellent, incredibly high value (several tapas are free) and the people are warm and friendly. It feels "casero" meaning as if it's homemade. If you're looking for something fancy, don't come here, but if you want delicious food, warm people and a truly authentic tapas experience, you're in for a treat at Bar Respiro.  A few tips:  -find Violeta, the owner  -you'll need to be prepared for very little English  -a few of the tapas are completely free! This is what the real authentic places do. I suggest the patatas bravas, the chicken and the chorizo.  -the tortilla is very good and typical of what you find in the authentic tapas bars  Enjoy!

A definite must if you want to experience Madrid night life like a Madridleno or Madridlena.

title_review: Amazing tapas at a ridiculously cheap (free even?) price
review_preview: Such a great experience! Came after a local recommended it. All the tourists know of another Tapas place next to El Respiro called El Tigre, and I went to both, but El Respiro is way better in terms of the quality of food they serve....
review_full: Such a great experience! Came after a local recommended it. All the tourists know of another Tapas place next to El Respiro called El Tigre, and I went to both, but El Respiro is way better in terms of the quality of food they serve. The "free tapas" (which comes with an order of a drink) at El Respiro are smaller in size compared to the gigantic plates at El Tigre, but the quality is way better. I believe the price of the drinks are cheaper too. Servers are so friendly and fun. I went alone and don't speak a word of Spanish and still had a great night. 100% recommend!

title_review: Great value & very friendly -tapas free with every drink
review_preview: We stumbled upon El Respiro one evening while walking around central Madrid and it appealed to us as it seemed like a very local friendly pub in the middle of a busy city. It was a Friday evening and it was teeming with locals having...
review_full: We stumbled upon El Respiro one evening while walking around central Madrid and it appealed to us as it seemed like a very local friendly pub in the middle of a busy city. It was a Friday evening and it was teeming with locals having after work drinks. The atmosphere is very relaxed and friendly and we were surprised to get handed three dishes of tapas with every drinks order we put in. We figured this was just an initial gesture upon arriving in the pub but we actually got another three dishes (and a different variety) when we ordered a second round of drinks (there was just two of us). The food was tasty and the portion sizes were big. All in all it's a very nice, quaint low key bar in a very central location.

review_preview: If your wanting a cool area to jump from bar to bar, see wonderful and interesting people, hear street music and grab a quick bite then Malasaña is a great area. We found Ojala by chance as our other choice was too busy. We got...
review_full: If your wanting a cool area to jump from bar to bar, see wonderful and interesting people, hear street music and grab a quick bite then Malasaña is a great area.  We found Ojala by chance as our other choice was too busy. We got there about 9:45pm but managed to grab a table. The staff were attentive ( and super super fast ... I think they like to roll their tables thru quickly on a Friday night)  We ordered a jar of sangria which was refreshing but very basic. If you're looking for a great sangria I would leave that for another time. The tapas plate was ok .. But the breads waay too hard. I had the chili con carne as a starter which was tasty if not a bit bland, followed by the tacos which were very nice. We also shared what turned out to be (basically a toasted chicken and cheese sandwich. I wouldn't bother with the last one  Overall - it was okay for a late dinner. But you can't help looking at other places in your way back to your accommodation thinking "ooh .. wish we'd seen this place earlier " if you know what I mean

We enjoyed a number of fresh tapas, including made at the table chicken tempura, baby squid and a Spanish omelette. But really, you can't go wrong with any of the choices. Finish the day off with a nice bread pudding, which will add inches to your waist line the moment it touches your lips. A great restaurant in downtown Madrid.

We arrived early, but they said they did not open until 12:30 so we wandered around and then made our way back to the restaurant. Even though it was chilly we ate outside in the enclosed patio, which was heated. We had a wonderful meal and a white Rioja, surrounded by locals many of whom seemed to be known by the staff. Delightful way to began our trip!

title_review: Loved it so much we booked a wedding here!
review_preview: We had eaten here several times on trips to Madrid, so when our daughter decided to have her wedding luncheon in Spain we booked the wine cellar room for her wedding.  The staff was very helpful with the planning and everything went off without any...
review_full: We had eaten here several times on trips to Madrid, so when our daughter decided to have her wedding luncheon in Spain we booked the wine cellar room for her wedding. The staff was very helpful with the planning and everything went off without any problems. The room was tight, but so picturesque that everyone loved it. The staff even arranged for a tuna band to play, and for a wedding cake to be delivered and even supplied the traditional sword to cut the cake (which delighted the groom, and made his brothers all envious!). We have returned several times after the wedding for mid day dinners at Los Galayos with friends and family, usually large parties of 6 to 10 or more, and have always had wonderful experiences. The last time it was just the two of us (last week), and the staff still remembered the wedding and treated us like VIPs. We will return here again and again. It is not your typical "touristy place", even though it is located right in the Plaza Mayor. You will love it for just drinks and tapas, for lunch or dinner, or for a special occasion.

title_review: Good Restaurant But Watch Your Euros
review_preview: Los Galayos is a slightly pretentious restaurant on Plaza Mayor with very good food.  We ate outdoors on the Plaza and enjoyed our meals.  Service was professional.  We were surprised to read on the menu that there was a charge of 2+ euros per person...
review_full: Los Galayos is a slightly pretentious restaurant on Plaza Mayor with very good food. We ate outdoors on the Plaza and enjoyed our meals. Service was professional. We were surprised to read on the menu that there was a charge of 2+ euros per person for bread and olives. This seemed high, so we followed the printed advice on the menu and declined - which caught the waiter by surprise. When we paid, the bill was automatically converted from euros to dollars without permission being sought. Based on exchange rates in effect at the time, this increased the cost of dinner for each couple by $3.50 (relative to using our credit card with 0% foreign currency transaction fee).

The penne noddles were very cheesy and topped with diced tomatoes. The service was a tad slow and we had a few different waiters throughout our meal which made it awkward when we asked for ketchup from one and never got any so we asked a different waiter only to have the original waiter bring us some just members before the second waiter returned with a bottle. Other than that it was great! I will defiantly eat at Ojala again!

review_preview: Arrived/settled in Madrid late on a Friday afternoon, hungry and eager to look around. My boyfriend and I were staying in the center of the city, and our host recommended this place to us. It was 10-12 minutes away from the Airbnb and one of...
review_full: Arrived/settled in Madrid late on a Friday afternoon, hungry and eager to look around. My boyfriend and I were staying in the center of the city, and our host recommended this place to us. It was 10-12 minutes away from the Airbnb and one of a few restaurants with outdoor seating in a small plaza. It was a gorgeous day and we were lucky to get a table outside. We started with chips and guacamole, then I got the salad with chicken and a glass of white Sangria. The guacamole was done perfectly, thick and mildly chunky with great flavor. The salad was mixed greens with grilled chicken, a hard-boiled egg, croutons, avocado, and sun-dried tomatoes in a light creamy dressing. It was delicious and very filling even for a small-ish serving. The sangria really blew my tastebuds though. It was sparkling white wine with cointreau, mint leaves, grapes and a few bits of cubed pineapple. It was both beautiful and sooo tasty. This was followed by a slice of their "zanahoria" aka carrot cake, which was one of the best I've had. My boyfriend agreed and that's one of his all time favorite desserts.  The food/drink quality was amazing and the location great. I felt like I was sitting in the middle of NYMag's street style section with tons of super hip people. Only thing that wasn't great was the service (a little slow), but that's irrelevant because the food will keep you coming back for more.

review_full: I just love this place. It is located in the heart of the popular hipster neighbourhood Malasaña. It is definitely my favourite restaurant of the ones I’ve visited in Madrid and as fas as I’ve understood, in the nights it becomes a club. It is well decorated and has a cool vibe, the basement has a beach theme with sand. The food is good, and the hummus is somewhat a speciality of the place. Depending on the day and time, you might have to wait a while before you get a table but its worth it. It’s not a cheap restaurant in Spanish standards but still, it’s affordable and I gladly pay for the good food. Never been disappointed!

review_preview: This is a large restaurant with both outdoor and indoor seating, located in Plaza Mayor.  On arriving to this place we found that the primary concern of the staff was to know the name of our hotel, presumably because of some kick-back arrangement.  Our first...
review_full: This is a large restaurant with both outdoor and indoor seating, located in Plaza Mayor. On arriving to this place we found that the primary concern of the staff was to know the name of our hotel, presumably because of some kick-back arrangement. Our first waiter was extremely pushy, returning every two minutes to get our order, when we clearly weren't ready. He must have been exasperated, because after about six attempts in 10 minutes, a second waiter took over. The food itself was uninspired, with the predictable items that can be found anywhere (but better prepared). The assorted cheese platter consisted of 10 slices of mancheco, and a couple of a second cheese. The rest of the food was similarly drab and did not taste freshly prepared, with the main theme being salt.  In short, there is simply no reason to eat in this place. The location is great, but if you must sit in Plaza Mayor, just order drinks.

title_review: Avoid if you don't speak Spanish
review_preview: first nite in Madrid went on a wine & tapas tour which is how we found this place. Three days later while out & about decided to try to try it for lunch. The outside seating had 3 tables of customers in various stages of...
review_full: first nite in Madrid went on a wine & tapas tour which is how we found this place. Three days later while out & about decided to try to try it for lunch. The outside seating had 3 tables of customers in various stages of their meal. The person who seated knew we didn't speak Spanish and he showed us the English pages of the menu. The waiter who took our order did not and was annoyed...especially when I asked for the menu of the day which does not come in. English. He gave options which was not what arrived, the salad was soup, which was ok. The FISH was squid..I don't do squid. Luckily my husband does and I was able to swap with him. My mousse au coco was white with a swirl of raspberry. He said that's what it is! Not once during the meal did he check to see if meal was ok, or if we needed anything. No apology for dessert or offer for alternate. The only reason it got as many stars as it did was my soup was good and my husbands fish was good. I am writing this review at the hotel the same day of the meal that's how annoyed I am!! We had even discussed returning for dinner for the suckling pig but sorry you sucked the last euro for my wallet

review_full: The first time we tried eating here, we were ignored for a very long time so we just left. We came back however, three weeks later, on the day before we left Madrid. Fortunately we arrived at about 6:30 on a Thursday night and we were able to place an order. Unfortunately, I left behind a small blue backpack that held some items of importance and value. I contacted our hotel (Lusso Infantas; five star rating IMHO) and asked for their help in retrieving the bag. They went out of their way to help, but the lazy people at Stop Madrid would not cooperate. They refused to turn the bag over to the hotel staff. They did not respond to my Emails offering to pay for shipping. They refused to walk the three blocks to the hotel to turn the bag over to them. As a consequence, the lazy staff at Stop Madrid Jamoneria, decided that I had waited too long to retrieve the bag, so they dumped the bag and its contents and told me that I could kiss my hopes goodbye of ever retrieving the bag and its contents. Although I don't expect to be back in Madrid soon, I am grateful that I am able to leave this extremely negative feedback and I encourage any readers to avoid the place.

title_review: Very unpolite, rude and not friendly at all !!!
review_preview: I am not one to write reviews often(not at all actually), but for this once i make a huge exception. Being it for the worse though.To my understanding human beings can have a bad day or the restaurant might be busy.But in my...
review_full: I am not one to write reviews often(not at all actually), but for this once i make a huge exception. Being it for the worse though. To my understanding human beings can have a bad day or the restaurant might be busy. But in my life time of 23 years, have i never been treated so rude and with such impoliteness by any restaurant staff at all. But this was a first for me, i heard a lot of good stories about Ojala, they are supossed to be this great place, with nice food and friendly staff... The Opposite was true for us. We entered the restaurant and i instantly got this claustrophobic feeling, it was so small and everyone was clusterd together and the at the atmosphere was very very humid! Since it was very busy, me and a friend were waiting in the queue for nearly 5 min for a table to come available. So there it was the FREE table, since we eventually were first in the queue we asked the lady if we could sit there. She refused to appoint the table to us, cause we were just with 2 and it was a 4 person table. We said alright no problem we will go somewhere else. The moment we left a couple behind us, (who didnt have a reservation since they asked if they could have a table aswell) was allowed to sit on that very same table. So we turned around and said to this unpolite waitress  " why is it that we just asked if we could sit there, you refused. Now the exact same amount of people (2) asks to sit there and are instantly allowed to sit there'' She than said on the most rude and sarcastic way: '' Listen my love, a third person is coming'' The funny thing is the couple were seemingly dating, so we had our doubts that a third person was coming. Anyway... She said, good bye and litteraly pushed us outside... 45min later we walked by Ojala again because we ate somewhere else, the same couple was still sitting there with just the 2 of them... Conclusion, if you like polite, honest and good service, do not go to Ojala. I was very enthousiastic to go there at first, but i would never advice it to anyone. If you want some good spanish food, with a nice quality service, there are better places to go. As i said before, i am not the typ that complains or even writes reviews at all, but for this ''restaurant'' i will make a exception... This is a zero quality and rude place that can not even be called a restaurant since they treat customers/guests as numbers and not as a human beings. Kind regards, A Dutch guy who normally doesn't bother to write a review... Think twice, before going here guys! Went here on the 26th of November

review_preview: We went to Ojala because we heard it had the best brunch and the rumors were true. The place and the decoration is trendy and new, the menu is big but to the point. The prices are just right, for 10 Euros you get your...
review_full: We went to Ojala because we heard it had the best brunch and the rumors were true. The place and the decoration is trendy and new, the menu is big but to the point. The prices are just right, for 10 Euros you get your meal, coffee and a drink (juice/beer). They also have the usual mimosas and bloody maries! The food was tasty, small portions, but tasty. A second taste revealed a very poor wine indeed and a third a mediocre but drinkable roble. We declined on the bottle but accepted two copas since we were there. When we asked for the bill we were confronted with a demand for 4 copas not 2 on the basis that we had accepted tastings of the bad wines. I initially refused to pay until we had discussed the matter but the money was forcibly taken from me by one of the owners whilst the female screamed for the policia at the door. The policia were satisfied very quickly that we were not in the wrong and we walked away but to be treated like this is disgraceful.  I am saddened to say that there are far too many businesses in Madrid who feel entitled to bully and extort innocent customers often on the basis that they may only be in the city on business.

review_preview: We visited La Plateria Bar 4 times within our 5-day stay in MadridWe almost despaired to find a decent restaurant in the touristic area of Madrid. Normally the prices are unreasonably high and the food quaility wish much to be desired. After having bad...
review_full: We visited La Plateria Bar 4 times within our 5-day stay in Madrid We almost despaired to find a decent restaurant in the touristic area of Madrid. Normally the prices are unreasonably high and the food quaility wish much to be desired. After having bad Lunch experience in the Museum area, we decided to have dinner in the restaurant near our hotel.   On the way to Metro we were enticed by the inviting look of paella and cosy atmosphere of La Palteria. So we decided to give a chance to the place. Good wine, tasty food, big portions and very considerate service. Very reasonable pric.  It was in February and we took a table outside. There was mobile heating to make us warm and comfortable.  Afterwards we returned to La Palateria 3 more times. Also for lunch.  Everytime we were treated with welcome littile starter while waitng, and once even by a dessert. Sepecial thanks to the peruvian waiter (sorry, forgot the name) it was high-class service. And we never had to wait for a long time even if the restaurant was full. Very good value for money and tasty indeed.

title_review: Excellent homemade food - huge, delicious portions!
review_preview: My friend and I arrived here on a rainy Friday afternoon. It's a tiny restaurant but there were some seats available and we quickly grabbed them. We were given menus but also advised that there were some recommended items for the day - the tortilla...
review_full: My friend and I arrived here on a rainy Friday afternoon. It's a tiny restaurant but there were some seats available and we quickly grabbed them. We were given menus but also advised that there were some recommended items for the day - the tortilla con calabacin (a frittata with pumpkin), the croquetas de tomate y hierbabuena (tomato and mint croquettes), the albondingas de lentejas roja y coco (red lentil and coconut meatballs), and tacos!  I had seen the reviews and read the owner's blog and knew I wanted to try the tortilla and croquettes and her freshly made bread. My friend ordered a pincho (slice) of the tortilla which came with a small basket of bread and the croquettes (6 units). I ordered a bocadillo (sandwich) of the tortilla.  Everything arrived after an adequate amount of time without problem. The tortilla is amazing. Maybe one of the best tortillas I've ever had INCLUDING non-vegan tortillas, of which I've tried many of the best in the city. I loved it. However, it is quite sweet due to the pumpkin. The pincho (slice) is big enough to share between two people and costs 3.50 (bread included).  The croquettes were perfectly cooked and huge. Unfortunately I didn't like the filling. Tomato and mint is just a weird combination for me. However, I know that the croquette flavors change regularly so I am eager to return to try and different flavor combination.  The bocadillo was also massive. I was presented with a toasted baguette (homemade) topped with a pincho of tortilla. I loved every single bite.  Overall we spent 17.50 euros and just under an hour here. I will definitely return for the tortilla and to try more things. I 100% recommend this place to vegans and vegetarians. You can tell it's authentic food - I also recommend checking out the owner's blog (same name as the restaurant). Her story and philosophy on food is very interesting and genuine.

title_review: Our most favorite Tapas during our whole time in Spain
review_preview: This place was amazing. And our tapas guide said that it’s even frequented by the royal family. We didn’t meet the king, but we did get to try out his chair and the food was so good that I was tempted to lick my plate...
review_full: This place was amazing. And our tapas guide said that it’s even frequented by the royal family. We didn’t meet the king, but we did get to try out his chair and the food was so good that I was tempted to lick my plate (I didn’t, but I wanted to). I especially enjoyed the tortilla, and an oxtail dish made from a real fighting bull. This place is a must for us on any/every return trip to the Spanish capital city. ¡Muy excelente! El ultimo.

review_preview: We took a Tapas Tour in Madrid and this was the first place visited. The Tapas was excellent, and the wine selection, too. We decided to go back for a full meal on our last night in Madrid. We sat in the back dining room,...
review_full: We took a Tapas Tour in Madrid and this was the first place visited. The Tapas was excellent, and the wine selection, too. We decided to go back for a full meal on our last night in Madrid. We sat in the back dining room, filled with antiques, old photos of Popes, dignitaries, and ancestors, and white clothed tables. They also have a middle dining room, a tapas area, a bar in front and outdoor seating. The service was impeccable and attentive. The food was expertly prepared. My Husband had a lamb dish and I had squid with ink over rice. We also had some asparagus that was amazing. It is one of the closest restaurants to the Royal Palace and it is said that royalty would go to eat there. The Alabardero were royal guards, so the restaurant is named after them.

review_preview: I had been to Julian in Tolosa some years ago, and enjoyed the place, the food and the atmosphere. It was nice to see it in Madrid so I gave it a try, and I am very glad I did. In a place with too...
review_full: I had been to Julian in Tolosa some years ago, and enjoyed the place, the food and the atmosphere. It was nice to see it in Madrid so I gave it a try, and I am very glad I did. In a place with too many pseudo restaurants serving mediocre food and offering mediocre if not deficient service, it is an oasis of first class food, service and setting. Beef is the best I have had in a very long time, the restaurant offers a nice quiet room in which to enjoy your stay, the owner is attentive to the guests, and the whole meal and stay is anenjoyable experience. While beef chuleton is something you definitely want to try at least once in your lifetime, there are other good choices, such as fish, or beans that are excellent. Salads and deserts are also very good, and there is a complmentary liqueuer to help you on you way. Highly recommended.

title_review: Probably one of the best restaurants in Madrid
review_preview: Taberna Ubeda is such a great place! It is tiny and charming, very authentic and not touristy. It is quite hidden, but if you want to have a table to sit on you should reserve in advance.The food is outstanding. I highly recommend the...
review_full: Taberna Ubeda is such a great place! It is tiny and charming, very authentic and not touristy. It is quite hidden, but if you want to have a table to sit on you should reserve in advance. The food is outstanding. I highly recommend the Tomato Salad, Albondigas (best I have ever eaten), the Solomillo in garlic oil and the Pulpo. Every single dish is to the point, I've been here several times and it was always spot on! Value for money is very good as well. Solomillo and Pulpo are around 20€ each but definitely worth it, all other dishes are around 8-10€. Very good selection of wines, we had a decent red tempranillo last time for 16€. I will come here as often as I can during my remaining two months in Madrid, it's just a great dining experience.

review_preview: I had lunch at El Perro Gamberro today.  I had their Hamburger del Perro (which was both delicious and enormous), a bottle of sparkling water, a glass of red wine and a coffee for €15,50.  The hamburger was lentil and mushroom - I think it...
review_full: I had lunch at El Perro Gamberro today. I had their Hamburger del Perro (which was both delicious and enormous), a bottle of sparkling water, a glass of red wine and a coffee for €15,50. The hamburger was lentil and mushroom - I think it was one of the best hamburgers I have ever had (even if I count the ones I had in my meat eating days). The staff offerred me a menu in English, which is good for anyone visiting who is not confident with the language. The waitress was attentive, the food was very well presented - overall a very good experience I can recommend highly. They also offerred Vegan options of tortilla de patatas and croquetas de alcachofa (artichoke), both of which looked amazing.

title_review: Popular bar and restaurant, excellent food
review_preview: We were recommended by our hotel to try Ten Con Ten on our first night in Madrid. We were not disappointed. It is a popular and noisy bar and you can eat in the bar, on the terrace or in the restaurant. We ate on...
review_full: We were recommended by our hotel to try Ten Con Ten on our first night in Madrid. We were not disappointed. It is a popular and noisy bar and you can eat in the bar, on the terrace or in the restaurant. We ate on the terrace, and needed the overhead heaters as it turned out to be a cold night. The whole place was packed. The food is typical Spanish, very well prepared and extremely tasty. Staff were numerous, professional and helpful.  This is not the place for a quiet, intimate dinner but if you want to eat in a bustling location, full of locals, and eat excellent Spanish food, you will not go wrong here.

title_review: Excellent food, hot spot for high society
review_preview: When you enter the restaurant, you are immediately greeted by a relaxing, good music and self-conscious waitress. You will be seated according to the perceived standing of yours in society. Tourists, like us, needed to stay in the front (high tables). There are other, more...
review_full: When you enter the restaurant, you are immediately greeted by a relaxing, good music and self-conscious waitress. You will be seated according to the perceived standing of yours in society. Tourists, like us, needed to stay in the front (high tables). There are other, more elegant tables as well.  Food: simply excellent. Pure enjoyment. I can highly recommend avocado-orange salad, very seldom have I tasted anything so close to perfection. My husband had stake and he shared my sentiments exactly. Wines were good too. Good desserts, excellent coffee.  They will charge you for the bread separately regardless whether you will have any. Moreover, they will add +10 VAT to the bill, which I have seldom seen in Madrid.  Service was quick and friendly. We were lucky with our waitress, she was grear. there are however others, who seem to have forgotten who is a customer and who indeed part of service personnel. But I guess there is a possibility to swim in a small bubble when all your customers represent the local high society, mas o menos.  Regardless of the amusement related to all of the above, it is worth the visit. The food is simply superb.

review_preview: We asked our hotel to make a reservation for us. We tried to book for 9pm on a Friday night as we thought the place would be deserted if we arrived any earlier. The hotel came back to say they could only find us a...
review_full: We asked our hotel to make a reservation for us. We tried to book for 9pm on a Friday night as we thought the place would be deserted if we arrived any earlier. The hotel came back to say they could only find us a table at 8pm. We imagined turning up to an empty restaurant so we were totally surprised to arrive at 8pm & find the front bar area buzzing & several tables already occupied in the back restaurant. Within 20 minutes most of the tables around us were occupied. If you think that locals don't eat until 10pm, you will be pleasantly surprised. We ordered 2 gin & tonics to start. Amazing! Best g&t I've ever had. I had thought the menus would only be in Spanish (& so I'd translated the menu into English before we got there so we'd know what to order) but we were presented with menus in English which was really helpful. Despite the restaurant becoming very busy (I think every table was reserved) service was good - timing was perfect - not rushed yet always attentive.  The covered patio area looked nice but we saw people smoking in there so we were pleased that we weren't sitting there.  This is a really good, lively restaurant with great atmosphere, fabulous g&ts & delicious food

review_preview: Bait and Switch is the disrespectful game at this restaurant. We researched long and hard to find a good restaurant featuring “suckling pig” or “cochinillo”. The top 3 had no seating available so we opted for a 4 star “Asador Real”as they claimed to have...
review_full: Bait and Switch is the disrespectful game at this restaurant. We researched long and hard to find a good restaurant featuring “suckling pig” or “cochinillo”. The top 3 had no seating available so we opted for a 4 star “Asador Real”as they claimed to have the best roasted pig straight from Segovia.NOT!!! They promptly showed us a plump hind quarter of the pig with nice brown crispy skin and told us they would cut it up and bring it back to our table. With our watering mouths,hunger and excitement we waited. The waitress brings back the pig and to our surprise it was the head with ears and a plate full of sloppy fat and bones!!! Just awful!!We were furious and hailed the waitress and manager to explain their intentional and deceitful switch as he tried to explain it away and the waitress smirked!!We asked them to remove it and bring a piece that actually had pork meat on it, but we were now so angered by the audacity to outright deceit us we did not eat the new portion. We also ordered the “Chuleton” which was tough. They ruined our dinner and it’s our duty to inform others.
