review_preview: It is 10 :30pm on Sunday March 10th and I am sitting at the bar (have been since about 8pm). Instead of trying to remember my experience here a week from now, I'm going to relay it while still sitting here.Location-wise it couldn't be...
review_full: It is 10 :30pm on Sunday March 10th and I am sitting at the bar (have been since about 8pm). Instead of trying to remember my experience here a week from now, I'm going to relay it while still sitting here. Location-wise it couldn't be better. Nestled in a courtyard across the street from the Prado this place has been hopping for the two days that I have been staying here (the Radisson about 50 yards away).  While obviously I haven't sampled everything on the menu it is far more diverse than most similar restaurants in the city. Prawns, Sole, Baby Lamb, Cod, Hake, Duck Confit - much more diverse than the the usual octopus and other repetitive tapas you'll find in Madrid. I had two small plates: the foie gras and artisanal bread (which ended up being too much bread even for me who needed the bread to soak up the vino I've been drinking. To be clear, the "foie" is of the terrine variety so if you are not a fan you will likely poo-poo this review. I love both, and I found the terrine to be excellent. The beer and wine options are more than adequate but if you a wine snob then go to a wine-oriented establishment. They have a wine list by the bottle and they post their wines by the glass in the bar area. Along with the menu they post the "Plateria" on a couple of chalk boards which they will bring to your table if your eyesight isn't what it used to be. Spanish on one side, english on the other. What I love about this place especially is the energy. Many patrons inside and out and the locals apparently know many of the employees personally. Because of this, the staff moves at a fast pace. Do not be afraid to make yourself known but don't expect butler service. Best to know what you want to order in advance, be it food or beverage. That being said, they will try to help you if your spanish is "muy mal" (bad). "Escusa me" = "Excuse me" and "Puedo tener" = "May I have". Attempting these simple polite Spanish words will go far. It's now 11pm and my phone is about dead. Having eaten and drank at many establishments around the world, I am confident that you will enjoy this place so long as you are in happy + relax mode.

Good wine served by the glass, we had the albariño, very nice with seafood. We liked it so much we were back here a few nights later to sample other dishes, all equally worthy. Reasonable prices. Definitely recommended.

Would recommend the restaurant & good value for money.

review_full: My friend and I were traveling for a couple weeks in Portugal and onto Madrid. The hotel recommended EL BARRIL DE LAS CORTES as a good restaurant for Paella, and i must say it was excellent. So disappointed they were out of lobster, however the Paella we chose was excellent. The thing that surprised us the most was the friendliness of the servers. We neither spoke any Spanish, so it was up to the servers to help in many ways. May I add we are 2 American women, but were treated with such respect and hospitality. Our server ELENA was fantastic from the moment we walked in the door. We were the first 2 diners of the evening! A fantastic meal, with the perfect ending of lemon sorbet with (in) champaign! OMG! My most favorite finish to any meal from now on! If you are fortunate enough to have the opportunity to visit this establishment, GO!

review_preview: LOCATION: It’s done really nice and it’s recommended to book a table as it was fully booked out from 21:30.SERVICE: We (2 people) did not book a table so we had 1,5hours time to eat. Therefore, the waiter asked us if he could also...
review_full: LOCATION: It’s done really nice and it’s recommended to book a table as it was fully booked out from 21:30. SERVICE: We (2 people) did not book a table so we had 1,5hours time to eat. Therefore, the waiter asked us if he could also bring our second dishes first if it’s ready faster than the starters. As we did not care too much about that, we agreed. Unfortunately, my second dish came, then both starters and in the end my friend's second dish (in the meanwhile the side dish was cold). Maybe we misunderstood the waiter but it's an unwritten gastronomic rule that you're serving the different courses of a meal at the same time. FOOD: The food itself was good but one starter was almost cold when it arrived so it tasted like a dish from the microwave (what a pity as I am sure it would have been much better!). I've had way better Chinese food before with a better price. For us it was slightly disappointing as we imagined more for the price (in another Chinese restaurant we went some weeks ago we had the same amount plus 2 deserts and a bottle of wine for the same final price). MOOD: When we arrived, there were about 5-6 more guests. After a short time, we heard a loud discussion (more a fight) in the kitchen between two staff members, followed by plates being thrown on the floor. As we guests heard all of it, it was kind of killing the relaxed mood for some minutes and something like that should never happen in any restaurant when there are guests!  So we both agreed that it’s a nice restaurant but we won’t visit it again as the price was too high for what we got... A pity for this location

review_full: I live in the suburbs of Madrid where Chinese food is uniformly terrible, so I tend to shovel it in when I visit London, like a Szechuan squirrel storing dumplings for the winter. I'd never tried El Buda Feliz before, despite it being the oldest Chinese restaurant in Spain. Everything I ate was delicious - better than anything I've had here and most in the UK. And that was the menu del dia (4 courses for 15 Euros, because Spain rocks). Nice relaxed lunchtime atmosphere too. Looking forward to returning.

title_review: Best Fried Green Tomatoes Outside Charleston
review_preview: For those of you not from the United States, or not familiar with the fried green tomatoes of the American South, you just need to know that Maricastana has perfected this recipe.  It's right up there with the best of the best.  But that wasn't...
review_full: For those of you not from the United States, or not familiar with the fried green tomatoes of the American South, you just need to know that Maricastana has perfected this recipe. It's right up there with the best of the best. But that wasn't the only thing great about this place. The service was friendly and competent, with the servers always willing to make eye contact so you can get what you need. We also had their Sandwich Maricastana on two of our visits, and loved the combination of flavors. The Menu del Dia is always a good choice, but we ordered from the menu and got just what we wanted. Highly recommended.

review_full: The open windows, rustic-chic decor and soft lighting gave this restaurant instant appeal. The menu was one of those with too many good dishes to choose from. Service was a bit slow but I think that's the norm in Madrid??? Anyway, my husband had the duck, which was flavorful but a little dry in spots, and I had a pumpkin tarte that I had been told would be like and omelette (not even close). It was a flatbread and a bit on the dry side and pumpkin was not a topping - the crust itself was made of pumpkin which I couldn't really taste. Loaded with veggies but it was missing something. I'm guessing cheese was left off to keep it vegan? Maybe hummus might have been a nice accompaniment. Food fell short.

title_review: Delightful Meal and Drinks - Fantastic Space
review_preview: Had a delightful meal, ordered 4 dishes and the waitress immediately understood that we wished to share them so delivered plates and utensils for each of us in anticipation of the arrival of the food. Despite being the only server our waitress was appropriately attentive...
review_full: Had a delightful meal, ordered 4 dishes and the waitress immediately understood that we wished to share them so delivered plates and utensils for each of us in anticipation of the arrival of the food.  Despite being the only server our waitress was appropriately attentive to our needs, brought our drinks as soon as the bartender completed making them (we were in view of the bar), checked on us, offered the dessert menu etc. The vibe of this bar/restaurant is unpretentious-cool, with good music at a volume low enough to easily speak with one another but loud enough to create a mood. I would highly recommend this restaurant and intend to return before leaving Madrid for a second round of fantastic.

title_review: Delicious, Quality Tapas on Ferraz, Around the Corner from Parque Oeste
review_preview: The tapas range from jamon, bacon/quail eggs to revuelto with smoked fish...all delicious.  Everything on the menu can be shared.  I highly recommend the chipirones and the risotto, but I have always enjoyed everything I have ordered in my many visits there.  Usually, I stop...
review_full: The tapas range from jamon, bacon/quail eggs to revuelto with smoked fish...all delicious. Everything on the menu can be shared. I highly recommend the chipirones and the risotto, but I have always enjoyed everything I have ordered in my many visits there. Usually, I stop in and sit in the bar area but I have also made reservations for the back dining room. There's no outdoor seating but there are great tables in the bar area by the front windows. In the summer, it is tempting to enjoy outdoor seating offered at various restaurants/bars along Paseo Pintor Rosales, but Cuenllas is my top choice hands down when not lured away by outdoor seating. Reservations are good for evenings after 9pm because the bar area can get crowded. The bartender is not overly friendly but he takes care of what you need and often provides great direction on what to try. The wait staff is very friendly.

review_preview: Had a great lunch after walking in by mistake. We had been told to go to "gran Barrill" but walked in here and had a great seafood and fish lunch. Boquerones en vinagre highly recommended and both of us are very picky with boquerones. Also...
review_full: Had a great lunch after walking in by mistake. We had been told to go to "gran Barrill" but walked in here and had a great seafood and fish lunch. Boquerones en vinagre highly recommended and both of us are very picky with boquerones. Also recommend the Cocochas al pil pil for a main (they're hake cheeks), revuelto de bacalao (codfish omelette). Several good wines by the glass. The service is typical Madrid for a good restaurant: older waiters, not super friendly but correct. I would go back.

But don't let this stop you from going, what I saw come out of the kitchen looked fresh and smelled wonderful and I wished that I was hungrier. Also the place was spotless and I would not hesitate to eat here again, though I would forgo the angulas and order something else.

review_preview: This restaurant was packed with many locals and tourists and there was a large variety of fresh seafood on display. Their seafood was fresh and a lot of selection to choose from. We asked the waiter to recommend something and his response was very thing...
review_full: This restaurant was packed with many locals and tourists and there was a large variety of fresh seafood on display. Their seafood was fresh and a lot of selection to choose from. We asked the waiter to recommend something and his response was very thing is fresh and named some prices of the seafood but didn't really suggest anything. He was busy we understand; so we asked for a few more minutes. We ordered a pound of grilling shrimp and a pound of gooseneck barnacles. It was our first time trying gooseneck barnacles so we didn't know how to eat it. Another waiter walked by and saw us struggling so stopped to show us how to open it. title_review: Great place to eat what locals eat
review_preview: This place was recommended by Suites Vienna Hotel staff, and was only couple of blocks away. It is not a tourist place, in fact they had only one person who spoke a few words of English. The place is packed with locals, who seem to...
review_full: This place was recommended by Suites Vienna Hotel staff, and was only couple of blocks away. It is not a tourist place, in fact they had only one person who spoke a few words of English. The place is packed with locals, who seem to be very friendly with the owners and servants. The restaurant serves tapas, but the french influence is noticeable with foie in the menu and french cheese table and vintage french wine labels on the wall. The service is very attentive despite the language barrier, the food surprised with some unfamiliar to us ingredients and flavors and was well presented, and the bill was very reasonable. The menu is relatively short, a small group may be able to try quite a few things in just one visit, but there is no reason not to visit at least once.

review_preview: The food here was delicious. It is not cheap, but not as expensive as the decor and service might suggest. We paid $100 euros for a lunch for three, where two of us had wine (a very nice Rioja recommended by our server). We arrived...
review_full: The food here was delicious. It is not cheap, but not as expensive as the decor and service might suggest. We paid $100 euros for a lunch for three, where two of us had wine (a very nice Rioja recommended by our server).  We arrived late, around 3 pm, and the place was filled with Spanish businessmen. People seemed to be finishing power lunches all around us, and many of them seemed to be regulars, well known by the staff.  The server started by bringing us a country pate and toast, for which we were later charged $3.50 each. That seems common in Madrid, but just recognize that the nice starter is not free and refuse it if you don't want it.  The service was pleasant and very attentive. The server gave us helpful suggestions in English. We had a wonderful appetizer of foie gras on toast, as well as a salad of borata and tomatoes that was pretty standard. Our main courses were the octopus, the hamburger, and the special fish of the day, a butter fish. All were very good. We were too full to have any dessert.

You had a choice of dinner and the show or drinks and the show. I chose the 55 euro dinner which was a three course with a drink and water. The show started 8:30 and lasted until 10:30. It was totally worth it. I watched the show alone and totally enjoyed it. The staff are really friendly and kind.

title_review: Two Hours of Breathless Dancing and Music
review_preview: My husband and I recently returned to Cafe De Chinitas after 34 years, half expecting it to have changed. Not at all.  We were thrilled to see that it is still one of Madrid's best Flamenco experiences.  The dancers covered three generations, and though subtle,...
review_full: My husband and I recently returned to Cafe De Chinitas after 34 years, half expecting it to have changed. Not at all. We were thrilled to see that it is still one of Madrid's best Flamenco experiences. The dancers covered three generations, and though subtle, it was obvious that the "senior" member was superior, pleasing us very much as we, too, are now seniors. The dancers' energy was almost overwhelming and with a table next to the stage, intimidating as if any second,  one of them might jump off and land in our laps. There are two shows nightly, and the Spanish audience shows up for the 2nd one. Feel free to yell and scream. They do. A free glass of icy sangria is included in the price of admission.

title_review: An authentic place with flamenco show

However, I noticed overheard a lady complaining about the cost of the dinner (She said 55 Euros for 2 persons) apparently she did not find it valuable. All in all, I recommend Cafe de Chinitas for a Spanish night or a flamenco show.

title_review: good food but a bit confusing
review_preview: We enjoyed our visit and it was extremely popular with the locals(Sunday lunch) This area of Madrid is similar to Knightsbridge or Kings Road in London i.e. a very posh mix of fancy shops and extremely expensive residential.The menu is rather confusing to a...
review_full: We enjoyed our visit and it was extremely popular with the locals(Sunday lunch)  This area of Madrid is similar to Knightsbridge or Kings Road in London i.e. a very posh mix of fancy shops and extremely expensive residential. The menu is rather confusing to a Brit as the blend of tapas -v- large main meals can't be deciphered by price. Luckily with pidgin Spanish we got a blend of "starters" which effectively were tapas and all was fine. But we could easily have spent a mammoth amount of money ordering way too much food. Lovely building and a brilliant waiter (ABDEL)

So, in summary, kitchen works, front of house needs to improve.

title_review: a great meal in Madrid with ambiance

The menu wasn't huge, but everything looked good. I went for the tacos, and I was not disappointed.  The ambiance here is great, and when I went downstairs to the bathrooms, I found another room that looked like it could be booked for a private party, or simply enjoyed by folks who were interested in a quieter space. Very cozy spot, and surprisingly delicious food! I'd come back.

title_review: A creative Chinese hidden in central Madrid
review_preview: This is one of the most talked-about restaurans in Madrid right now. A Chinese chef, an ugly bar with just 6 tables upstairs and roughly a 10-day waiting list. There is no menu, the chef will just ask you about any preferences and allergies and...
review_full: This is one of the most talked-about restaurans in Madrid right now. A Chinese chef, an ugly bar with just 6 tables upstairs and roughly a 10-day waiting list. There is no menu, the chef will just ask you about any preferences and allergies and will cook whatever he bought that day in the market (it helps that the Mostenses Market is right in front of the restaurant). He brings a mix of traditional and innovative Chinise dishes, a mix of meat, fish and seafood with explosive sauces (tomato- and sweet & sour - based). He will continue putting dishes on your table until you tell him to stop. The price is correct in my opinion for the quality and the mount of work included, and it's definitely an alternative chouce for a night out in Madrid. Recommended.

title_review: GREAT FLAMENCO ... and even better flamenco CLASS !!!
review_preview: I'm an expert in Flamencos. I know them almost all in Spain, and some in Latin America. I have to say this place is one of my favorites. No precisely for the food, which is pretty much average .... but you don't want to go...
review_full: I'm an expert in Flamencos. I know them almost all in Spain, and some in Latin America. I have to say this place is one of my favorites. No precisely for the food, which is pretty much average .... but you don't want to go here for the food, but for the flamenco show.... it is a great place. They have 5 dancers (bailaoras), 2 guitars, and 2 singers which creates an outstanding experience !!! do go !!!! I took a group of 22 people from my company and they all just LOVED IT. Now, if you really want to impress your group, call in advance and book a flamenco class, just for your guests. You will have it after the show and the dinner, when the place is alone for you. You will pay €25 per head, additional to the show, but you have no idea how GREAT this is ... your people are going to love it ... Carmen, the dance-teacher is amazing.... so beautiful but most importantly, a GREAT disciplined teacher who will show you all in 90 minutes what an amazing thing Flamenco is ... you and your people are going to love it !!! ( I repeat myself, food is not the best )

title_review: Creative menu, excellent food, cute design.

Quirky displays, lighting, tables and chairs, and excellent acoustics. The menu del dia didn't have a lot of choice, but everything was delicious. The tuna steak was particularly good - pink and moist. The portion sizes are perfect - you don't end up over-eating, which is what usually happens to me when I have a traditional Spanish menu del dia. Will definitely go back here!

We talked to the waiter and she told us that really the banana was a little bit green. And changed out desert for the cheesecake - that was really good. They also talk in english for the ones that don't speak spanish. It was a really good experience and I recommend to everyone.

review_preview: We were wanting to see a Flamenco show and thought that this was a city to do it in.  After reading Tripadvisor reviews we decided on this one.  It was also close to our hotel so we could walk and take in some of the...
review_full: We were wanting to see a Flamenco show and thought that this was a city to do it in. After reading Tripadvisor reviews we decided on this one. It was also close to our hotel so we could walk and take in some of the sights and nightlife in the plazas. We made reservations and gave ourselves lots of time to get there.When we arrived the dining tables were all set with beautiful linens and cutlery. We were seated at a table for two facing the stage. No craning our necks or turning our chairs around for us! We looked at the plates of food that others were being served and asked for an upgrade. They were very accommodating and even took a discount on the cost because we had bought show tickets before coming. Every course of the meal was delectable. Sauces that had exquisite taste all to themselves and not overpowering the meat or side served. Salad course was delicious; fresh and plentiful. The show started and our waiters quietly continued to cater to our needs and clear and bring the next course. We did not leave hungry! The show itself was just as the other reviews described: enthusiastic, lively, loud and very varied between the singing and dancing. Costumes were vibrant and warrant notice. I believe there was a male guest performer who was a real treat. At the end of the show one must admire their stamina. The other unexpected treat were the walls of the reception area. Here you can view decades of photos of royalty and celebrities who have enjoyed this cafe. At first we thought the prices were high but in retrospect we were given poorer quality of food, less quantity on the plates and for higher prices at other restaurants in Madrid - and no show! We would go back.

review_full: We dined at El Barril while on a family holiday in Madrid. The decor is pleasant enough, but the wheels fell off soon after we sat down. A relatively expensive bottle of wine that came undrinkably warm (took the servers 15 minutes to cool it appropriately, but which time most of us were almost done eating), and all the meals came at different times so no one was eating together. Very disappointing way to end a holiday in an otherwise highly gastronomic city!!

review_full: It's cozy and pleasant but as we know, restaurants make their name with food and service and maricastana has space for improvement in both. It's hard to figure out what they really are about, the menu reads kind of sophisticated b but in reality not spectacular and missing clear character. Most visitors we saw wee young people sipping their tea or wine. We ordered some food from the main courses list. My tarte flambee with ham and ruccula was very tasty but also very difficult to eat as all ingredients were falling off the pastry basis. My partner's tarte flambee with bacon and onion was mostly about onion and even that was just too dry. Although both dishes were "main courses", we both left with lots of room in our stomachs. We found it quite amusing as none of us is a big eater and normally we have the opposite problem. Maybe it's just a place where young women like to come and the portions are suitable for a girl who does not want to risk a surplus of calories.  But it's not cheap for what you get. Maybe I wouldn't be so grumpy if we had more luck with the waiter. Unfortunately the young man was not at his best that night and his effort was kept to correct minimum. I was very disappointed when I ordered tea and in spite of my explicit request for earl grey git just plain English, the bag already in my cup. To make matters worse it turned out later that they actually have a big choice of nice tea flavours but he didn't bother to offer me an my choice. So no, not in my good books and Madrid has a lot of better alternatives.

title_review: Nice bar/restaurant minutes from Gran Vía
review_preview: Corredera street is one of those busy, charming and narrow streets that run off the hectic Gran Via. the Maricastana is both a bar and a restaurant. During  weekdays it offers an attractive fixed price menu and in the evening its mainly a place to...
review_full: Corredera street is one of those busy, charming and narrow streets that run off the hectic Gran Via. the Maricastana is both a bar and a restaurant. During weekdays it offers an attractive fixed price menu and in the evening its mainly a place to enjoy drinks (there is a theatre opposite) with people beginning to order food from 9.00pm onwards. The bar area can get very crowded but there is a downstairs clear which is much quieter and with very comfortable chairs and armchairs. The food menu is 'modern Spanish' and prices are what one would expect from a trendy place on a very popular side street just off Gran Via. Service is very friendly. The crowd of young people at Maricastana seem to be mostly Spanish.

review_preview: Hi, my wife and myself found Cafe De Chinitas by chance as we stayed in a nearby hotel. We booked an early evening show with dinner on a Tuesday.  Whilst not full, the atmosphere was great and the flamenco was spectacular and the paella was...
review_full: Hi, my wife and myself found Cafe De Chinitas by chance as we stayed in a nearby hotel. We booked an early evening show with dinner on a Tuesday. Whilst not full, the atmosphere was great and the flamenco was spectacular and the paella was arguably one of the best we have ever had. For the price we paid the evening was of unbelievable value (paella (too much), bottle of wine, gazpacho starter, bread, ice cream dessert). The show lasted approximately 2 hours and was quite spectacular with at least 5 solo performances which were mesmerising. What a treat! One of the highlights of our stay in Spain! Thanks Cafe De Chinitas! Best, Steve & Esther

review_preview: We were visiting Madrid with family and meeting some Spanish friends for dinner, Cafe de Chinitas was recommended as our friends wanted us to see a show. I was a little apprehensive as were my family as we had never seen a flamenco show before...
review_full: We were visiting Madrid with family and meeting some Spanish friends for dinner, Cafe de Chinitas was recommended as our friends wanted us to see a show. I was a little apprehensive as were my family as we had never seen a flamenco show before so we were not sure what to expect. I must admit we were all blown away by the performance, it was amazing. The dancers and singers/musicians put so much effort into it and it was very emotional. Even though there wasn't many in the audience they still put so much effort in for those that were there.  You can just pay for the show and have a drink or you can also order food. We shared a number of small dishes as starters and then had a main and a pudding each, they were nice but the crochets were a little strange. I had the salmon along with my mam and it was lovely, my partner had the veal and my dad had the steak and everyone enjoyed what they had. I must admit the show and the atmosphere were fantastic but I found the food and drink quite expensive, but if you are wanting a traditional Spanish evening I would highly recommend. It's a little bit of a walk from Sol but worth it for some tradition.

review_full: This is a small place that is tucked away on a side street. Event with our local hosts we had a difficult time finding it. We were seated 2 rows from the stage which was very exciting and loud. If you are bothered by loud noise ask for a table further away. The performance featured 4-5 gentlemen on guitars and vocals, a male dancer and 4 women. They each had their own style and look. This was my first Flamenco Show so wasn't sure what to expect and was pleasantly surprised. Our local hosts said it was very good.  We had a large lunch before the show so ordered drinks, spanish omlette and a cheese plate. The price was high but the food and service were very good. Until I see a better show, I would recommend this one.

review_preview: What a disappointment.  After doing our research about where to eat in Madrid, we made a booking here.  Perhaps the process of making a booking should have been a clue--the phone was not answered twice and, on the third call, it was, with the person...
review_full: What a disappointment. After doing our research about where to eat in Madrid, we made a booking here. Perhaps the process of making a booking should have been a clue--the phone was not answered twice and, on the third call, it was, with the person hanging up the phone after the booking was made without so much as a "see you later" or "thank you." (Note: the person making the booking speaks Spanish.) We arrived and no one greeted us; after several minutes of waiting, we finally went to the back of the restaurant and asked about the booking. The server pointed to a table and we sat down. Menus were pretty much thrown at us. The major issue at this place was the service: there was one waiter working upstairs and he could care less. He rolled his eyes at customers throughout the night and clearly just did not want to be at work. When we asked him about one dish ([here was one food term on the Spanish menu with which we were unfamiliar (this place does not offer English menus)] we got a eye roll and not very helpful response. Plates were thrown on tables with no commentary; he would have his back turned to walk away before the dish had even stopped moving from the force with which it was placed on the table. The only thing he went out of the way to do was show you how much your enjoyment did not matter to him.  In addition to being rude, the service was also error-prone. We ordered a bottle of wine (he even verified this before walking away) and were served and charged for glasses. We ordered three appetizers and an entree; we were served only two of the appetizers we ordered. The food was forgettable. We began with completely flavorless croquettes; they were basically all bread. The arugula and pumpkin salad was acceptable but overdressed. A chicken caesar sandwich was so drowned in mayo that the sauce fell out of the sandwich when you attempted to eat it and it tasted like nothing else. The decor is cute but the combination of disinterested and rude service and poorly executed food make it tough to call this place anything but terrible. I can't imagine how they would treat a customer who doesn't speak Spanish given how rude they were to Spanish speakers. Don't waste your time here; there are plenty of good options elsewhere in Madrid.

title_review: Tasty Paella, friendly service, a nice meal in Madrid.
review_preview: We walked place the restaurant earlier in the day and thought it looked nice, so we dropped back at dinner time, I was really looking for a good Paella, and after luckily sneaking in without a reservation, we ordered the large prawn paella. The service...
review_full: We walked place the restaurant earlier in the day and thought it looked nice, so we dropped back at dinner time, I was really looking for a good Paella, and after luckily sneaking in without a reservation, we ordered the large prawn paella. The service was quick and warm, we received a complimentary starter, an octopus tart, and a complementary dessert, a one bit piece of simple sponge cake. This was a nice surprise, and both complimentary pieces were tasty. The paella came out and frankly was very nice, plentiful prawns, and not too salty. Add two glasses of red from Rioja, and the entire meal cost about 50 euros.

The food is great, in particular their Paella, waiters are very attentive and the Flamenco performance is fantastic! I recommend trying to eat before the show starts, as you will not want to take your eyes off the stage. They also run the famous restaurant La Bola, which has been serving authentic Cocido Madrileño, the traditional way in clay pots since the late 1800s. Great overall experience in both places!

review_full: Everybody wants to go to Botin for the Cochinillo, but getting a seat there can be a challenge. If you want to taste Madrid's cochinillo, Asador Real is a very good alternative. For around 33 euros, you'll get a quarter leg of young pig that's more than enough for two people. It's perfectly cooked and it's surprisingly non-oily broth is a perfect dip for bread. Service is very friendly and since most of the serving staff are Filipinos, they understand English very well.
